titleStmt.title: Site Index of the Nell Nelson Restoration Project
titleStmt.sponsor: Elisa Beshero-Bondar: Newtfire server at the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center

respStmt.resp: with assistance from the Digital Mitford Project and the Digital Humanities courses at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg from 2014-2016, from

editionStmt.edition: First digital edition in TEI P5, date: 2015-12-12. This digital archive began as Rebecca Parker's in-depth capstone paper and presentation for completion of a History based Social Sciences Bachelor's degree at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg. Work to create the digital aspects of the project begain in the Fall of 2014.

availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file have been extracted from files in the Nell Nelson Restoration Project and the corresponding GitHub page.

person.note: Rebecca Parker is a senior at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg. She is a double major of English Literature and Social Sciences. Rebecca's area of focus within the Social Sciences is History and she is on track to receive the Digital Studies Certificate. The Restoration of Nell Nelson is a project Rebecca began research for during the Spring 2014 Semester, for her history capstone. Rebecca's interest in Digital Humanities stemmed from her involvement on the Digital Mitford Project working as Dr. Beshero-Bondar's Green Scholar. Rebecca is an active member of Sigma Tau Delta, Pi Gamma Mu and Phi Kappa Phi.

Elisa Beshero-Bondar is Associate Professor of English at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg, where she has enjoyed working since 2004. She regularly teaches 19th-century British Literature, Early American Literature, Social Literature, and Science Fiction, as well as an interdisciplinary course on text encoding in the Digital Humanities. She is a member of the University of Pittsburgh's Digital Humanities Research Group (DHRX) and the Indo-Pacific Council (INPAC). She is also the lead Faculty Advisor for the Pitt-Greensburg Alpha Alpha Delta Chapter of Sigma Tau Delta, the International English Honor Society. A lifelong student, she is very much a work in progress.
Rob Spadafore is a Creative and Professional Writing Major at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg. He is also editor-in-chief of the school newspaper, The Insider.

Cody Karch is a student at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg, with plans to transfer to the main campus. His major is English Writing, but will be going into a duel-major in that and Philosophy eventually. Pitt-Greensburg's Digital Humanities Class is what got him involved with this project. He is helping to transcribe, and support the formation of Nell Nelson project alongside others.

Kari Womack is a student at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg. She is a Sophomore VAPA (Visual and Performing Arts) major with a concentration in Theatre and is currently the Props Master for the campus 2015 Fall production of Middletown. She is an inductee of the Delta Psi Omega Theatre Honor Society and has previously held the positions of Stage Manager, Assistant Scenic Designer, Assistant Technical Director, and Backstage Manager.

Shane Daube is a graduate ('14) of the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg. He is a Psychology major looking to pursue a master's degree in Clinical Psychology or a related field. Shane became a member of this project when he took Pitt-Greensburg's Digital Humanities Class in Fall of 2014. He worked to help Rebecca transcribe, markup, and XQuery the Nell Nelson articles from The Chicago Daily Times and also the chapters of the McEnnis text.

org.note: The multiple street addresses are for each place in the article that is commisioned to do the needlework of said company. The addresses are listed here in the order they appear in the article. The second address was listed in the article just as the number 163; however, it was in succession with an address on West Taylor so it was assumed to be same street.

location.placeName: Corner of Clark Street and Washington Street
Northwest Corner of Adams and La Salle
Southeast Corner of Adams and State

bibl.title: Chicago By Day and Night: The Pleasure Seeker's Guide to the Paris of America
bibl.author: Paul Durica
Bill Savage

org.desc: Meetings and such held in St. Stephen's church, which is the address below.

org.note: The first address associated with this just said 158, but was following a company being exposed on West Taylor street; therefore, the street name associated here was inferred.

location.placeName: Corner of La Salle Avenue and Locust Street
Sedgwick street near Division and Superior

org.note: A spelling error is printed in article CT011: the company is misspelled as "Olson"
In article CT014, this company is only briefly mentioned in a list, and it is possible this is misspelled; it might be the same company as "#Oleson" in articles CT011 and CT021.

location.placeName: 118 State Street. Next to the Boston store.
201 Pullman Building; Corner of Adams and Michigan
the southwest corner of Wesson and Hobbie streets on the North side

org.note: Mentioned in article when Judge Horton is quoting Judge Arington's poem.

location.placeName: the corner of Elm and Wesson streets

org.note: Tshe address associated with this just said 196, but was following a company being exposed on West Taylor street; therefore, the street name associated here was inferred.
H. Zimmerman is also referred to as "the good jew".

nym.p: Nell Nelson: Helen Cusack-Carvalho used the pseudonym Nell Nelson when she wrote the "City Slave Girls" series in 1888. She was employed by The Chicago Times and then later, following the success of her series in Chicago, hired by New York's The World. The biographical information on Helen Cusack-Carvalho is considerably illusive and currently anything remotely close to a complete biography of her is nonexistent. The primary source of biographical information comes from a journal article by Eric W. Liguori published in 2012. In this article, Liguori alludes that Helen was born into the middle-class and that her career as a journalist allowed for her to maintain this status. Liguori reports that Helen married above her social class to a man named Solomon Solis Carvalho in 1895. After marriage, Helen's journalism career ceased to exist and she lived the remainder of her life raising their two daughters. According to an obituary found in a 1945 New York Times' publication Helen died in New Jersey. The obituary lacks any special recognition of her investigative series despite the popularity and influential effects it had on the labor reforms of the late nineteenth century.
Reference to any employee that is either recognized as a foreperson directly in the text or given rank over other employees in some way.
Reference to owners of establishments, and their familial ties.
Reference to any employee thar is not a woman or foreperson.
Reference to a specific archetype found in article 1888-08-02.
Reference to an otherwise unlabeled character that speaks on the behalf of another person (typically family tie speaking on behalf of an employee/working girl).
Identifier used when context is unclear for who/the archetype that is being referenced.
Reference to a man that is either alluded to or directly referred to as a prominent Chicago figure.
Reference to a woman that is either alluded to or directly referred to as a prominent Chicago figure.
Identifier used when it is clear thar Nelson is not person responding in an investigation/interview, or if context for reported information is more generally unclear.
Identifier used for George Bodgers of the health department (was present in 1888-08-10 article undercover with a Times reporter).
